availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: James H. Husbands (Graves County, Kentucky, attorney and soldier.)

body.p: Graves County, Kentucky, attorney and soldier. Kentucky native. Son of James B. Husbands and Maria S. Martin Husbands. Attended school in McCracken County, Kentucky, in 1850. Household owned three enslaved persons in McCracken County in 1850. Graduated from the Law Department of the University of Louisville in Louisville, Jefferson County, Kentucky, in 1856. Attorney in Graves County, Kentucky, in 1860. Household owned one enslaved person in Graves County in 1860. Served in the 1st Confederate Cavalry (C.S.A.) as first lieutenant and captain from March 4, 1862, to May 15, 1865. Captured at Henry County, Tennessee, on January 6, 1864. Prisoner of war at Rock Island Barracks, Rock Island County, Illinois, from January 16, 1864, to January 21, 1864. Prisoner of war at Camp Chase, Franklin County, Ohio, from January 23, 1864, to March 25, 1864. Prisoner of war at Fort Delaware, New Castle County, Delaware, from March 27, 1864, to January 20, 1865. Prisoner of war at Fort Monroe, Virginia, from January 26, 1865, to February 2, 1865. Paroled on May 15, 1865.
